134.desc: Amazing benefits, Brilliant people, Lack of process and structure (Team dependent)
134.pros: Microsoft clearly cares about their employees. Their benefits and the way they have made sure the culture is centered around taking care of the mental health and health of employees above all is present through every level of Microsoft.The people you work with at Microsoft are mostly brilliant. Everyone is a true nerd/engineer at heart and it can be extremely energizing to work amongst such intelligent and creative people.I have had a great experience with my manager at Microsoft. They were an incredible advocate in my career and worked to get me all the opportunities I needed to further my career.
134.cons: There is not a standardized software engineering cycle process like Agile implemented throughout the company. This means that how your team functions and handles projects is extremely dependent on the manager. With no set process through the company, there is no set infrastructure to take pressure off of engineer for monitoring, deployments, testing, etc. This results in engineers taking on a lot of work outside of design and implementation.I also believe there is a large gap between business and engineering specifically within Azure. It is a high demand sector of Microsoft. There is a lot of changing business requirements that impact engineering work and timelines. I have been involved in many projects that were used as quick fixes for a business requirement then scrapped.
134.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  a*****  Software Engineer I - Apr 25, 2022

389.cons: Bureaucracy and processes are paralyzing. Internal documentation and engineering tools are very poor. 401.desc: Great Place to Start and/or End
401.pros: - Lots of global, high-impact projects available over huge variety of teams/products- Colleagues are generally friendly and supportive- Very good WLB (except on-call -1 star, see below)- Exciting place to work due to brand and frequent media coverage- Great benefits (health, vision, Perks+ program allowing $1.5k for hobbies/sports, bus pass)- Beautiful campus (Redmond HQ)
401.cons: - Biggest is below-market pay once on-hire vest dries up. Doesn't catch up to market again until way up, L66+. Thus, bulk of workhorse of the company (L62 - L65) know they are underpaid resulting in lots of attrition in these core productivity levels. Management acknowledges, but says tough, deal with it year-after-year. Insulting refreshers ($17k over 5 years for Senior - not a typo). All this leads to lots of people resting and vesting.- I love MS stack, but after a few years you will be totally out of touch with technologies most other companies use.- On-calls are stressful, particularly in Azure. No reimbursement. Even if your service is stable/mature, still need to be under house arrest just in case, for days.- Internal transfer process is horrible. Basically need to re-interview like an external stranger.- There are lots of low-impact projects as well. Easy to get stuck wasting time with grunt work.- Slow career progression from L62+.
401.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  G*****  Senior Software Engineer - Apr 2, 2022

478.desc: I worked there before Satya's days so beware, still good place overall
478.pros: - Excellent work-life balance.- Great place to build your career.  The company is patient on your ramp up and the support structure is decently designed for juniors folks to grow at a reasonable pace.- Decent compensation.  Not top tier but still good especially considering the lower grind compared to the top tier FAANG places.- Lots of opportunity to work on interesting stuff.  As opposed to most companies, Microsoft has their hands on literally _everything_.  You can work on pretty much anything you can imagen tech-wise.
478.cons: - Career growth is really slow in some groups, so you need to be very conscious about this.- Too many levels compared to other companies, example: Google/Meta levels are equivalent to _at least 2_ @MSFT so progressing is a grind.- Politics heavy; really annoying.- Reorgs and strategic redirects are somewhat common so don't be surprised you might be working on something that will eventually get canned.- Not sure if it's prevalent in every group but there is some dead weight in some places which is irritating since if you put your hard work and see others coasting introduces a sentiment of unfairness.
478.resignation reason: - Career growth.  I stayed at the same level for way too long and I felt it was unfair.- Huge round of layoffs in 2014, many of my personal friends and colleagues got impacted, that was a serious downer for me.  After that I decided enough was enough.
478.authorInfo: Verified User Former Employee  b*****  Software Engineer II - Mar 27, 2022

479.pros: Still some good people left but most have left or leaving

This behaviour is modelled from the CEO so others feel they have to do the same.

773.desc: Excellent people, fun job, hobbled by bureaucracy and executives making bad decisions based on outdated perspectives
773.pros: The culture can be good but it has its flaws. I am a committed employee that will not be quitting anytime soon, the benefits are great (for the US - healthcare is a crapchute no matter where you go here), my deal has been pretty good.Best part of the job: feeling like I am making a change that can help people with the work I do in marketing, of all things!
773.cons: -There are many hard parts to the job, but many are not the job but the corporate atmosphere.-It can take years to even achieve incremental impact sometimes-Senior leaders often have been with the company or other corp environments for so long that they only understand an approximation of what less well-off people are like and have a hard time connecting with team members. it can makes some decisions, uh, interesting-It's a slow giant of a company, and you feel it in the time to execution seen in a lot of projects. -The approach for returning to office amid covid is also incredibly flawed. There are the company policies that everyone hears about in the news and Microsoft is lauded for, but each Sr leader can then dictate their org's policy from there. One team of thousands is required to return to office in person at least 50% of their working hours regardless of health risks to their personal situation. For roles that are not strictly necessary to be performed in person (ex. if you've been WFH for 2 years without issue) it should never be required that the employee should have to drive to a specific office building to perform the same job with results that are going to be not as good as when the employee had the freedom to choose where they work. It's less energy efficient, its less productive, its more stressful, its not aligned with promises of balancing work and life, and it's just plain wasteful to boot. -The churn right now is unbelievable
773.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  U*****  Marketing Manager - Mar 3, 2022

902.desc: Great WLB, hit or miss management, bad comp
902.pros: Work life balance is wonderful. I can set boundaries with my job and management respects that, and I've heard the same from many other teams. Nobody expects you to overwork or work weekends. Culture is ok. Some people are helpful and friendly, others are really crotchety and shitty. Basically what you'd expect from a huge mature company. They have pretty solid benefits (the best fitness, health care, and 401k I've ever seen).
902.cons: In Azure org you are expected to do on call without any additional benefits -- no extra compensation versus roles that have no on call, no company phone to take pages from, really just a shitty deal for you if you're unlucky enough to have an on call rotation. Compensation is, frankly, pretty bad and woefully outdated compared to other top tech companies. TC they offer is very underwhelming, especially when it comes to equity. Massive cliff after signing bonus stock is all vested and no refreshers. Management is hit or miss -- I've seen great and I've seen horrible. It varies wildly team to team.

954.pros: Managers are fairly relaxed about not micromanaging deadlines, other engineers are helpful when you have a question about how something works/why we do it this way, or they will link you to documentation (very hit or miss). Promotions are easy to get (level 62 and under), as long as you check in with your manager every couple weeks, or once a month, and they know you are trying, you will likely get a promo.
954.cons: Outdated and poorly maintained documentation, which people will link you, not realizing that it is no longer relevant. Potentially excessive on-call rotation (especially for Azure); this could be anywhere from 24x7 support once every few months, to 12 hours every few weeks. This caused me a lot of stress, but YMMV. Because of the aforementioned documentation, there is lot of figuring stuff out yourself even after asking for help (could be hard for early in career engineers). Initial stock award is okay, but the refreshers for level 62 and under are BAD. 10-20k per year, vesting over 5 years. The cliff is real, people.

993.desc: Great company - is what you make of it
993.pros: - great overall company. Satya takes the top down approach to driving values of integrity and inclusivity - great work life balance of you want it - leadership is generally pretty open to lateral moves around teams and orgs to support employee growth - Solid benefits package - Freedom to drive your own career path if you want that - diverse portfolio of products to learn a lot along the way (Azure, Office, Xbox, Windows, Git, etc)
993.cons: - Down side of the work/life balance is management doesn't hold teams accountable enough to deadlines. So it's hard to partner across orgs and expect they will deliver their component on time. It can be frustrating to feel like you're not moving forward quickly enough - career progression is heavily on your shoulders - it is also impacted heavily (for good or bad) by the relationship you have with your manager and skip.  For younger engineers I think this can be a struggle. Highly recommend having a respected mentor that is at least a band or two higher than you - Benefits are pretty great - one annoying thing is our health benefits are a high deductible HSA.  Luckily Microsoft covers most of the deductible (but only deposits their portion in two lumps sums, one of which is in the summer), so sometimes you get stuck doing the calculations and paperwork for reimbursements if you over/under pay earlier in the year- With the acquisition of Git Hub, LinkedIn, and standing up Azure as a Amazon compete — we've  hired (integrated) a lot of new personnel.  It's great for new ways of thinking — but there is an old guard vs new guard way of thinking in certain orgs.  People who have been in the company for 20 years have a this so how we've always done it mentality.  But it's very team dependent- Based upon my reviews here on Blind and Levels.fyi, it appears our annual stock awards are about half-ish (depending on level) of what the big FAANG's offer
993.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  c******  Product Manager - Feb 13, 2022

1212.desc: Good work life balance, mixed company culture and technical rigor.

1212.cons: Each product team is almost like it's own little company, so the experience as an employee will vary dramatically based on this factor. Compensation is below average vs other big companies, and as a result there has sadly been a lot of brain drain to those companies (except a few who stay for ideological reasons, or because they can't pass the more intensive interview process of some other top-tier paying companies). This has the secondary negative side effect that your coworkers may not be as competent as at other companies who pay top market rate, which can make a more frustrating experience as the increasingly top tier talent finds themselves burdened further with picking up more work that others are falling behind on.

1279.desc: Awesome new grad job, but growth is slow and comp is low
1279.pros: - benefits like WLB, 401k, healthcare, parental leave, perks+ etc are fantastic. I don't really like I have to worry at all about these things- good people (for the most part): MSFT has seen a HUGE culture shift since Satya became CEO in 2014. There are still some old timers who are kind of bahhumbug but they will retire soon 😂- MSFT cares about employees as humans. Not only do benefits get better YoY, but the pandemic has proven to us that employees matter. We were one of the first companies to fully remote- Culture of growth mindset (it's okay to fail as long as you learn from it and share that with others), empathy, working on D&I, and building on each other's work. These values are rolled across the company in many different ways but they are also standardized to an affect so you know they're being heard by everyone- deep pockets. Want to go to a conference? Go for it? Need swag for an event? Sure why not?- stability.
1279.cons: - slow career growth. even if you max out rewards and are being told you're doing an excellent job, once you are past level 60/61, you should expect 18-24 months between promos regardless of how well you do. Of course some groups are better about this than others but I've found more slow growth groups than others - TC. Sure the benefits are great but don't compensate for low TC compared to the other major tech companies. Base salaries are far lower and stock refreshers are at a much smaller scale. - established massive company. Can be good, but in this case is a con. So many hoops to jump through and random people for approval so they feel involved. Always feels like it takes 10x longer to get anything done and out the door. People also seem to be indecisive. Not sure if it's because they want it to be a group decision or if it's cause they don't want the blame if it goes poorly lol

1283.cons: It's hard to get a role equivalent to your skill set - you get placed based on your years of experience alone. I know people 3 or more levels above me that are beginner developers but got a role matching their years of experience either from another role in the company or coming in with an interview that was not technical whatsoever. 1306.pros: 1. People are usually very cordial and happy to help out. We have a value called One Microsoft that encourages collaboration instead of internal competition. The idea is that, despite being in different product groups and business functions, we're all part of one gigantic team. And that this company wide collaboration helps reduce redundant work and promotes cohesion.2. Management genuinely cares about employees' work / life balance, and there is a general sense that people prioritize their time off. You probably won't see a lot of people working over time here.3. We take Growth Mindset seriously. When you do make mistakes and don't achieve certain business outcomes, you are judged more by how you adapt and learn from those mistakes than by your past failures.
1306.cons: 1. Compensation is not as competitive as other Big Tech companies2. A relatively healthier work culture here means you not might be learning as much as engineers in other companies who are frequently working over time out of necessity. You will need to take the initiative to learn and ownership over your own growth.

Good leadership/management here shines incredibly bright and leads to a wonderful experience in the long term to the point where when it's missing, you really start to hate your life. -Generally interesting projects with the freedom to have a lot of say on how they are built out at every level
1557.cons: -Low pay especially when compared to competitors. Do your time and then as our CEO would say vote with your feet-Leadership politics are pretty horrendous at times; obviously depends on your org-There are definitely pettiness from upper leadership which can directly affect your trajectory. Advice is to kiss ass strategically-Leadership doesn't want to admit they need to do better with employee retention -Devs still rule the roost here so don't expect for them to be given guard rails to protect the company. If you work in security, you clean their mess. It's about reaction not prevention regardless of the double speak leadership states. -Work life balance is either horrible or great. Stay away from positions with on call at this company; they do not pay for it nor do they recognize your efforts on a regular basis. Most of Microsoft doesn't really understand what being on call actually means

2830.pros: Microsoft offers competitive compensation and flexibility in terms of hours. We work crazy hours on the Revenue Recognition team during quarter ends. This is known by our leadership team and they are trying to provide additional resources and scalability in other ways. Because quarter ends are extreme, off times are much more flexible. Leaders support taking recovery time after quarter ends. Busy quarter ends are expected with life in Revenue Recognition but it is in part made up for for flexibility outside of busy times.
2830.cons: Rewards are based on impact (personal impact is primary variable out of 3 items evaluated for rewards). Impact is in large part is outside the run work. There is limited time built in for these extra impact projects and therefore they often significantly eat into work life balance. Also, in your contract you have a max bonus percentage, it is RARE to get the full amount. Do not expect your annual compensation to include the full bonus amount. Average is about 50% of percentage in your contract.

Good Perks : Fitness policy, Health Insurance, WFH setup, Food subsidy, ESPP etc4. Great Culture : Culture is great and Managers always help for anything. (Supportive for moving teams as well). Many sources for self learning as well.5. Awesome Opportunities : As Microsoft is very large and involves in lot of spaces, there are lot of opportunities to explore & can easily find the team you wanted to work on.
2868.cons: 1. Work : There are teams which have very good work but many teams run in maintenance mode. So the work might be boring after some months. 2. Old technologies : As Microsoft's has lot of legacy product which are developed in early 2000's, are still in market and needs to be supported. So had to work on old technologies which might be very hard sometimes.3. Compensation: Microsoft provides good compensation but not as competitive as many companies and refreshers are also low.4. Ramp up : Most of the teams doesn't have documentation and will be very hard especially in WFH, for the first few months to ramp up. All views are specific to my experience and may vary from person to person.

3635.cons: Work life balance has declined significantly since the pandemic started. 3753.pros: 1. If you love tech, this is a great place. No doubt you'll talk tech (mostly the MSFT stack) from enterprise to consumer - from PCs to phones to Xboxes - from datacenter to desktop.2. What were GREAT benefits are now VERY GOOD (took a small step down) but still probably better than you'll find at 99% of large corporations. If you've got family - the value of the benefits is even higher. 401k match is nice.3. Even with it's struggles MSFT is still a cash printing machine. This means if you can keep your nose clean and do reasonable work, you can have a stable job, pay your bills, feed your family, and not worry (too much) about layoffs. The stock you own likely won't tank, but probably won't go up much either. You'll get a bonus each year and some stock. It's a decent life if you aren't looking to light the world on fire.
3753.cons: Brand on Your Resume: After many years of losing market share and struggling to be at the front end of innovation and the fact that there's 90,000 employees, don't think MSFT is necessarily going to be attractive on your resume to more agile and smaller companies.Managing Your Career: Make you say this out loud so it registers - 90,000 employees work there. Double that for vendors. It is VERY hard to stand out and move up in the company. Don't expect your manager to be much of an advocate or enabler to help you meet your career goals - they are basically trying to survive the stack rank every year too. Not familiar with the stack rank? Check out the 2012 Vanity Fair article called Microsoft's Lost Decade.
3753.resignation reason: After 10 years, I'm leaving - it's just a matter of time until I find the right opportunity. I need to find a company spends 90% of it's time building technology experiences, as opposed to 90% of its time building PowerPoints. And I expect to refuse the exit interview - because if you really cared what I thought, you wouldn't ask me after I decided to leave.
3753.authorInfo: Verified User Former Employee  x*****  Software Developer In Test - May 4, 2021

3928.desc: Great direction, great WLB, great SLT, meh middle management, low TC
3928.pros: Awesome SLT that is forward looking and has done an excellent job with acquisitions and long term bets. Meh middle and lower management, many, many of the M1's are over leveled and incompetent. Tons of smart people at the company though. Some teams are amazing, but the variance in quality between teams is high.Great WLB, and culture is relaxed but serious and genuinely interested in engineering and solving world problems. Still suffer from the 'old' Microsoft of moving super slow in some areas, and just being out of touch with obvious market opportunities. (They own Teams and Skype, but Facebook beat them to a videoconferencing device, and for some reason Zoom emerged as a winner?? Cortana existed years ago, but Google leapfrogged them? They had a video streaming service tied to XBox, yet somehow didn't develop that while Amazon built Prime Video? They didn't pay out for Twitch?? Honestly how did you guys let Amazon outbid you on Twitch?)
3928.cons: Comp has been in the dumpster for the past 5 years and wont get better, only thing keeping it remotely competitive is the stock rise, yet they still view themselves as a top tier tech company. They pay closer to IBM than they do to Facebook or Google these days. Also the 5 year vest is outdated but HR doesn't care. Lot's of top 5% talent has left, none of those folks stay around to wait for a Partner spot to open up, and you'll park for a long time at 66/67 unless you're in a high growth business.Zero adjustments to overall salary or comp package in about the last 8-9 years, though they did spot fixup some people with random stock bonuses a few years ago.Lot's of over leveled people crowding the Principal band in some teams, many of whom are garbage compared to the upcoming Seniors. You find more of this in the older products, lots of old dark corners to hide in, but it exists in some form on most teams.There are a fair number of teams that have grown too quickly that resulted in rampant overpromotion, whereas in other orgs even if you're great it can be difficult to level up to the high 60's because the biz moves so slowly. This has created significant unbalance in quality and competence at a given level across the company, so on one team your Principal GEM might be incredible but on another you have a completely incompetent Partner that somehow nobody is managing out.
3928.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  f*****  Principal Engineering Manager - Apr 15, 2021

4047.desc: Great company for WLB, culture | Not great for compensation, career growth
4047.pros: - Great WLB unless you are in India and your sister team sits in US.- So many projects of different domains you can try. If you think the current projects is not aligning with your career aspirations, you can chose to move in the new one. Microsoft senior leadership in Microsoft office team allows for internal shuffle every two years.- IC and manager relationship is good and healthy (as per my experience)- 1 large scale hackathon every year in July, and 2 org level hackathons where people can invest 1 week in each hackathon to try with some of their own projects- Microsoft is so much customer and employee-centric company. They always care about their employee's physical, mental well being.- Microsoft India has a special group called as Garage which organizes different kinds of workshops, learning groups on topics such as: Robotics, Quantum Computing, AI/ML, IOT etc.- Stock value and image of Microsoft is good in financial market.
4047.cons: - Overall career growth is slow. Unless your visibility is extremely high within your direct and sister team.- Poor compensation offered compared to competitive companies- You will see your value (monetary) value will decrease if you chose to stay in company for more than 2 years.- Senior leadership is good, but junior leadership (your Manager and skip level) is not that great. You can observe little politics their.- If you are in IDC (India) in a project that is lead by other sites such as Redmond (US), Japan, China, Israel, then you may feel like a vendor who is just helping them. You may not get good part of the projects which would actually help you in your technical growth. In that case politics is largely played at junior leadership level.- In some orgs promotion happens half yearly, so that's a drawback.- Microsoft is expanding like anything, they have now become mass hires like Infosys and TCS. The quality of hires and interview both has extremely degraded. So you might not feel special if you are hired OR you may see many not-so-good engineers around you.
4047.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  P*********  Software Engineer II - Apr 1, 2021

4332.desc: For those wanting a stable yet boring job with aspirations of middle management in the enterprise space.
4332.pros: - Work life balance. I have never been stressed on the job and have been able to achieve exceptional reviews with little work. In part because expectations are incredibly low for lower levels. Work will increase with higher titles.- Benefits are incredible (most are realized if you have a family to support)- a positive shift in culture attempting to be more inclusive and aware (but empathy can only be trained so far)
4332.cons: - Rewards based more on output and 'flashy' features rather than solid engineering, leading to rushed projects with short-sighted development and increasing technical debt.- Career is seen to only exist within Microsoft. If you stay long enough you will be siloed into a very specific technology that won't translate well to other companies. I wish there was a more holistic view of career amongst managers.- Managers for the most part are looking out for themselves and their own rewards. It's the exception, not the norm, to get a manager that actually cares about your career development and try to align your priorities with theirs.

4420.desc: Great WLB, good growth opportunities, open and inclusive culture, fantastic benefits but subpar long-term compensation
4420.pros: Most teams outside of Azure proper (in other words, not the Cloud teams) have great WLB with an emphasis on ensuring employee wellbeing. The enormous number of teams provides lots of opportunities to expand breadth, work with interesting technologies, and allows one to grow both their technical and soft skills. Company culture has continued to improve by focusing on these with efforts to allow for a great and inclusive work experience even during the WFH period.
4420.cons: Some teams can be hit or miss in regards to WLB, namely some of the proper Cloud teams within Azure (read: the Azure team includes both Cloud and the core OS/Windows groups, and it's the former I'm referring to).Some teams can be slow moving (good for WLB) which also slows down growth for those who don't proactively try to collaborate with partner teams.While the benefits are great, the almost non-existent stock refreshers for Bonuses/promos/rewards is distributed from a fixed budget for each team. This means that higher performing employees can unintentionally drop their colleagues' bonuses, even if everyone has high impact.

4516.desc: Great wlb and perks but ymmv for career/skill advancement
4516.pros: Work life balance is a huge plus, especially in covid times. Everyone is cognizant of different lifestyles and other than meetings at certain times, is completely fine with you moving your working hours around the day (ex. some ppl do a few hours later in the evening and start much later). Many employees have families and a larger out-of-work life, so they themselves prioritize that more and it makes there be less pressure for others to prioritize work. Definitely A+ for that. Perks are really nice. ESPP, 401k match, perks+ (1200$ to use on whatever we want per year), can establish a really solid financial foundation early on in your career. Tons of resources to use (linkedin learning, library, etc) if you want to learn new stuff.
4516.cons: Since WLB is so chill, it seems like there's very little momentum to get some things done. It takes a while to get approval from all parties and there's little motivation to make a large change if what exists works (even if there are major flaws). Because of that, there might be a lot of tech debt in the team, which causes for the technical skills rot that a lot of other reviewers mention. But it's ultimately up to you if you want to keep your skills sharp or learn new things. If you don't really push for it, then management will be generally be perfectly happy with you twiddling your fingers with the same old tech. No one will be really forcing you to learn new stuff, which might be a plus or a con (con for me since I'm early in career).

I think they're looking out for their employees, and doing a good job of communicating with everyone - especially now that we're all dealing with COVID.
4850.cons: I think it can sometimes be hard to get promoted.  My experience is that they'll promote you only if the business can support your promotion -  both in terms of what's needed in that role and whether they have the budget.  And, that makes sense, but if you're capable/ready for a promotion, and you can't get it on your current team, you have to transfer elsewhere and hope that the new team can support your advancement.

4973.desc: Ok until L64.. then it gets political very quick..
4973.pros: It is ok if you are the type that want to do 6-8hs and go home, and have an ok paycheck.-Good WLB- Many different teams and very interesting projects- Git is used on most teams these days- Not sure if a pro, but nobody gets fired. Literally I have no idea what you need to do to be let go. I have seen people make mistakes that cost the company $10M+ and management covering it up so the team does not look bad. Over the years I've have learned about sexual harassment cases, racial discrimination cases, etc that go on with just a slap on the wrist, and in some cases are even are followed by promotions.- Nice perks ($1200 for well being in 2021, free XBox Game Pass Ultimate, many discounts, etc)-Possible to rest & vest (if that is your thing)-If you are the political type, you can level-up every 2 years- There is a push to change company culture, but not 100% sure how successful it is below the surface. The issue is in general middle and higher management, who push that changes down but do not apply them to themselves.
4973.cons: Windows is everywhere and there is no knowledge within the company about anything external (Linux, Java, Rust, LLVM, Open Source, etc), so over time people stay and become totally disconnected of what is going on in the world and attach to the One Microsoft Way.  Strong push back still for things not invented at Microsoft. People from Windows team permeates the company as a whole, and in my experience, even when smart, they tend to be narrow minded and have a culture of bullying and pushing back to get their way. Build system and coding practices are in line with what you would expect from 20-30 years ago. If you want to master how to abuse C/C++ macros, coupled spaghetti code, the latest fad on .NET (not compatible with the previous latest fad), passive-aggressive push-back techniques, and convoluted COM interfaces, this is the place to be! Elitist higher management. Some people (L68 and above I know) will literally not talk to you unless you are above certain level; the issue with this is that they are totally disconnected from what is going on, living in a little bubble of privilege and filtering out whatever they dislike. In many teams you can only grow if you suck up and/or be silent and comply. My experience is that many employees are lifers and play favorites. Many managers are in just to build their little empires. If you are in a team with a weak leadership chain and are a high achiever this plays against you, as they may see you as a threat, actively suppress you, and will promote mediocre and worse only.By the way, at a certain level you are competing with all your peers on the org on the same band, so there is stack ranking, and above L64 it becomes toxic and political very fast. Compensation does not depend on impact, you have to fight for every cent, and then only if you are about to leave team they will throw something at you. Most money is used to make L67+ happy. Paying a big bonus for a DE/Partner can screw refreshers for everybody under their leadership for the year regardless of what you manager promised you (hint: middle manager can only do some damage control, they are not really empowered in this).Training is a joke for a company this size. Professional growth is totally up to you, and next to nil for management. You get some random subscriptions and good luck. Mentorship is flaky at best.No proper CI/CD anywhere I have seen. Pushing a change, depending on the team can literally take hours or days (if there is a conflict). Testing is as bad or worse as code, and looked down by most devs. At the end, before releasing, all this causes an incredible amount of manual labor for the most trivial tasks. Oncall for some teams takes most of the team effort because of this.Promotions are political, so the above keeps compounding over time until (periodically) a reorg is needed, and some within management are moved around (of course, without any external consequence or visible accountability).
4973.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  r****  Principal Software Engineering Manager - Oct 27, 2020

Just finding the right team, is all. - Leadership has changed a lot since I first joined and the direction has been really positive in comparison.  Plus the stock is doing great.

5239.desc: Average engineers, Average products, Average Management trying to stay relevant using its enterprise advantage.
5239.pros: Very very few good engineers who like to stay in Redmond bubble. These engineers are the reasons many teams still run. Few new good products, to keep industry engaged with Microsoft. Social and philanthropic policies at exec level are pretty neat & robust. Jobs are relatively stable. Pays are usually good at very very high levels.
5239.cons: Many engineers are hired for on-call purposes than to write code and are almost slaves for enterprise customers. Lots of toxic people and morale will be low in just few days working with them. Engineering mind set is very low innovative in nature, but to keep the enterprise customer happy with tiny features/improvements. Quality of engineering is poor & legacy services are passed down at least a half dozen teams in a lot of products/services, because of this engineering teams tend to work on support tickets with customers and/or some on-going existing issues. Re-orgs are pretty frequent, just to spread quantity of engineering evenly between bad and worse teams. Overall less of an engineering company, but trying to stay relevant with its past advantage.

5563.desc: It is what you make it
5563.pros: There is such a breadth of projects to work on that you are sure to find something you are interested in.  it also means that you can move around and continue growing and expanding your network no matter how long you stay in the company.  The benefits are great, and the work life balance is really what you make it.  I've been on very high stress teams and managed to keep a good wlb and I've been on low stress teams and worked too hard. Also, in the current climate, stability is a definite plus.
5563.cons: Depending on who you're comparing to, the pay can suffer by comparison.  There also doesn't seem to be much interest in changing that.  There are also a lot of people who are steeped in the Microsoft culture and way of doing things, so that can be stifling to innovation at times.  I'm not sure how the politics compare to other places, but they are definitely there and play a major part in your career progression.

It will also get you promoted.- Company wise, benefits are great and you feel valued as a person- Great environment to pick up political skills. You witness enough politics here to apply at future roles.
5564.cons: - Compensation below industry standards- Management only looking to show quick wins without fully understanding the technical problems needs to solve to support the product long-term- Lack of empathy from senior leadership for bad on-calls due to badly designed systems.- Leadership says the right things, but doesn't walk to talk- Career growth takes a back seat because you're constantly on hack mode and running after quick wins. Staying here long term means you can't ever leave. While this will get you promoted within the company, you won't be able to find another job outside the company at those levels.- Quality of tools are below industry standard.

5792.desc: Good work life balance but....limited career growth unless.....
5792.pros: Good work life balanceGreat CEO and leadershipCulture is collaborative but not necessarily super open (people wear the Microsoft Maks during meetings)The platform and strategy are great
5792.cons: I worked in Presales : 60% internal task (coordination, internal meetings, scalability, reporting, emails with tons of ccs, discussions, KPIs, stakeholder management .....)30% deliver the real thing to customer (beware of not being the last one on receiving a hot potatoe that does not drive impact and visibility, good tech, skill up is defintely possible)10% politics, politics, politics, personal branding, comm, comm comm....You need to understand the mechanics of the systems : Everyone will buy microsoft easy to convince customers, however the main skill here is to justify internally your impact on deals so it is mostly how good you are in communications, politics, relationships, branding, and being at the right place, on the right deal and at the right time. nd getting visibility towards the leadership. It is a judgmental organization, branding is everything !You need to also have your manager on your side, otherwise, expect no career growth. Managers have too much power in this organization and can easily slow down your career progression.People are usually not genuine, always come with interests, trying to put their names on deals for their own visibility, career aspirations. Very little are ready to genuinely roll up their sleeves for something that is not falling under their specific KPIs. KPIs overly drive behavior at Microsoft ! Not recommended for a smart, but introvert and genuine person. Need to be Political to survive.
5792.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  I*****  Sales Engineer/Senior Sales Consultant - Jul 18, 2020

5840.desc: In general better work life balance, but comp is usually one of the top reasons for talent drains
5840.pros: 1. Microsoft has variety of product lines to work on, for which you can almost certainly find something that interests you. 2. In general the work life balance is good, although Azure seems usually busier. When I used to work in a non-Azure team, I even witnessed colleagues who can be a full-time software engineer and part-time real estate broker at the same time! I think the added bonus is if you are thinking of startup, but you still want some steady income at first, you can try to land in a rest and vest team within Microsoft, and only quit to full-time startup when it's mature.3. 401k match seems like one of the best industry offering.4. Although lots of people crave for FAANG tier companies, the reality is they can't even get an interview opportunities. Microsoft is a good step stone to polish your resume and open the door to FAANG, although the best case scenario is to stay at Microsoft for only one year, and then knock the door.
5840.cons: 1. To be fair, comp is ok, if considering all the tech companies (numerous startups included) across the country. However, the comp is not competitive in the tech talent places like Bay and Seattle. Companies like F/G can easily poach the candidates from Microsoft. What's even worse is senior leadership knows the comp issue, as well as benefits issue, but is not willing to fix it. Meanwhile companies like F/G provide free food, Microsoft just added 10% food prices by not subsidizing the sales tax last year. Search in the internal Yammer threads, you can find lots of frustrations on comp and benefits.2. Slow promo. Microsoft leveling is messed up, it basically divides each level into two sub-levels at least. This for sure will make promo slower. Also the slow process at Microsoft makes it even worse.3. Proprietary tech stack. To be fair, this is improving, especially in Azure. However you can still see lots of old-time Microsoft people are obsessed with Microsoft proprietary stack. The result is when they publicize the stack, it can be beaten brutally. Azure data lake gen1 was a good example.4. Too PM-centric. If you have to work with a TPM who's not from engineering background, good luck! It can be a real pain to work effectively. However it seems like a good number of TPMs are actually from Sales/marketing/MBA background!5. Easy to loss motives. If you are not strongly motivated, but you are concerned about your comp, you can easily trap yourself into a vicious cycle of wanting to leap forward, but you somehow lose last mile of momentum. I had good number of leet buddies in Microsoft, and we spent lots of quality time to study. But guess what, only I left so far.6. Talent drain with senior or below engineers. Couple years back, Microsoft can still easily poach candidates from Amazon for senior or below engineers. However ever since even Amazon ramped up on the industry hire comp, Microsoft just keeps lowering its posture. There's even one instance in Blind, where people choose Nordstrom over Microsoft!7. Senior software engineer title recognition problem. There's a general perception that Microsoft L63 does not usually map to senior at FAANG tier companies, although it usually depends on interview performance. Coupled with slow promo, it's almost wise to leave at the sweetspot levels, which is L60 and L62. Another wise spot is to leave within one year of new grad, since you can still be considered a new grad candidate for some companies like Google.8. At most a 4-year stop shop, if you care about TC. Microsoft also has the secret cult of insultingly low annual stock refresh. A quick blind search will make you realize, target stock refresh for L65 is ONLY 36k/5yr. Once you run out of on-hire cash and stock, your TC will cliff miserably, not even on par with your first year, even if you exclude on-hire cash. This is in stark contrast with F/G like companies, where  5th year TC is at least comparable to 1st year TC, if you don't count on-hire cash.
5840.resignation reason: Pretty much all the cons above made me leave promptly.
5840.authorInfo: Verified User Former Employee  z*****  Software Engineer - May 15, 2020

5841.desc: Generally good work life balance, but it is team dependent. Comp is low, and the senior leadership is fake.
5841.pros: Decent work life balance if you land in a non SaaS or PaaS team. Compensation is ok, and the medical plan is really good.401k match is excellent and there is an opportunity for higher contributions through backdoor Roth IRA.The campus is very nice and big, with new buildings coming soon.
5841.cons: The senior leadership is very hypocritical and is only interested in PR stunts and not in fixing the root cause of issues (whether they are internal or external). Satya pretends to be a nice guy but in reality he is not very good at being empathetic towards Microsoft's employees. This trait seems to be common across the people on the board.Work life balance can easily get out of whack in teams which are part of SaaS or PaaS (e.g. Yammer, Azure, Outlook, etc.) with on-call rotations made difficult by the lack of engineers and too many buggy features.The constant request from clients to introduce new feature means tech debt is never address filling the code with bugs and making everyone's life more difficult. This is a sweatshop and pretty much a consulting business.Compensation is not competitive with Microsoft's main competitors, and in spite of the STL knowing about the comp issues, as people have been complaining about it yearly, they are refusing to address it.The talent is generally pretty mediocre, with a good number of engineers lacking basic knowledge about distributed systems, designing APIs and data encapsulation.
5841.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  b*******  Senior Software Engineer - May 14, 2020
